channel.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
channel.description: import java.util.Scanner; import java.io.*; public class Square { public static float number; public static void main(String args[]) { Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in); BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in)); System.out.print("Number = "); number = Float.parseFloat(scan.nextLine()); for(int i = 0; i <= 10; i++) { System.out.println(number + "^2 = " + java.lang.Math.pow(number,2)); } } }

item.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Its sorta a brute force…but its not slow because its a brute forcer.

Fermat’s theorem runs on the fact that any odd composite integer is the difference of two squares, a^2 - b^2. Therefore, a^2 must be greater than i, the odd composite integer. The factorization method therefore keeps incrementing a until a^2 - i = b^2 some perfect square, which is the “offset” for the factors - a + b, and a - b.

So its as simple as a general brute forcer. Btw, can you explain to me exactly what the big oh notation is? I have never found a clear definition of it - I know its an determines algorithmic complexity but does it actually return a value or something?

Read full topic
item.source: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter

item.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

It’s Fermat’s Factorization Method, which “brute forces” a relatively large integer by finding its form as a difference of two squares. Basically, it’s a method for finding the prime factors of odd, composite numbers. The actual method is not very difficult in terms of mathimatical complexity (you really only need a good knowledge of algebra to understand it), but it comes under the Number Theory category, which is why you’ve probably not heard of it.

Read full topic

item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I posted it to be used

It’s a really neat algorithm imo in regards to the theory behind it, but inefficient for such large numbers…it takes forever on the mc135 rsa modulus, which is only like 30ish digits whereas the 202 modulus is about 150ish. Its just not meant for semiprimes of such magnitude, having been published in like the late 1600s :P.

item.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Anyway ss you guys posted your leet math formulas I’ll add one of mine I just did for no reason 

import java.math.BigInteger;
import java.math.BigDecimal;

public class FermatFactorizationMethod {
    public static final BigInteger RSA_MODULUS_202 = new BigInteger(
        "7162900525229798032761816791230527296329313291232324"+
        "2902378492635012082079728940539290656365223631636210"+
        "00728841182238772712427862772219676577293600221789"
    );
    public static final BigInteger ZERO = BigInteger.valueOf(0),
                                   ONE = BigInteger.valueOf(1),
                                   TWO = BigInteger.valueOf(2),
                                   FOUR = BigInteger.valueOf(4);
    
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new FermatFactorizationMethod(RSA_MODULUS_202);
    }
    
    
    public FermatFactorizationMethod(final BigInteger i) {
        // Must be odd composite number
        if(i.mod(TWO).equals(ZERO))
            return;
        
        // Find k, the first value for which if squared is larger than i
        BigInteger maxKValue = i.add(ONE).divide(TWO);
        BigInteger kSearch = sqrt(new BigDecimal(i), 25).toBigInteger();
        while(kSearch.pow(2).compareTo(i) < 1 && kSearch.compareTo(maxKValue) == -1)
            kSearch = kSearch.add(ONE);
        
        
        System.out.println("k = "+ kSearch);
        
        
        // Run Fermat's Factorization method
        BigInteger iterationDifference;
        for(; kSearch.compareTo(maxKValue) == -1; kSearch = kSearch.add(ONE)) {
            try {
                BigInteger factorBase = sqrt(new BigDecimal(kSearch.pow(2).subtract(i)), 25).toBigIntegerExact();
                
                System.out.println(i +" = ("+ (kSearch.subtract(factorBase)) +")("+ (kSearch.add(factorBase)) +")");
                break;
            } catch(ArithmeticException e) {}
        }
    }
    
    
    
    /*
     * Algorithm used from http://www.merriampark.com/bigsqrt.htm
     */
    public static final BigDecimal sqrt(final BigDecimal originalValue, int divisionScale) {
        // Must be >= 1, otherwise doesn't run square root algorithm
        int maxIterations = 50;

        // Make sure originalValue is a non-negitive number
        if(originalValue.compareTo(new BigDecimal(ZERO)) == -1) {
            throw new ArithmeticException("Square root of a negative number.");
        }

        if(maxIterations < 1)
            return originalValue;

        BigDecimal lastValue = new BigDecimal(ZERO),
                   sqrtValue = getInitialApproximation(originalValue),
                   errorValue = null;

        int currentIteration = 0;
        boolean isCalculating = true;
        while(isCalculating) {
            lastValue = sqrtValue;
            sqrtValue = originalValue.divide(sqrtValue, divisionScale, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
            sqrtValue = sqrtValue.add(lastValue);
            sqrtValue = sqrtValue.divide(new BigDecimal(TWO), divisionScale, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
            errorValue = originalValue.subtract(sqrtValue.multiply(sqrtValue));

            if(++currentIteration == maxIterations) {
                isCalculating = false;
            } else if(lastValue.equals(sqrtValue)) {
                isCalculating = errorValue.abs().compareTo(new BigDecimal(ONE)) > -1;
            }
        }
        return sqrtValue;
    }

    private static final BigDecimal getInitialApproximation(final BigDecimal originalValue) {
        int totalIntegerDigits = originalValue.toBigInteger().toString().length();
        if ((totalIntegerDigits % 2) == 0) {
            totalIntegerDigits--;
        }
        totalIntegerDigits /= 2;

        return new BigDecimal(ONE).movePointRight(totalIntegerDigits);
    }
}

The code kinda sucks, but I just wanted to get it down for the fun of it…it runs Fermat’s integer factorization method on the RS RSA modulus…if you run it for a week or two you might crack it

Btw, I didn’t write the sqrt function…just the factorization portion.

item.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
item.dc:creator: @Galook Galook
item.description:
@Galook wrote:

[quote=“iwasinmoparseas101class, post:19, topic:13918”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=20821.msg237407#msg237407 date=1158096620]
Once again, why do you do this:

float a = Float.parseFloat(scan.nextLine());

im not sure, but i think he has to put a nextLine() method if he does it that way… I dont like using Scanner, but in a competition it was required once and i was told that after the nextInt() method, you need to use the nextLine() becase of a bug with the scanner, even if it is the onl thing in the line, the next time u use nextLine() after nextInt() you have to have a nextLine() before it(sorry if its confusing).

I know this applies to nextInt(), im not sure about nextFloat() though…

instead of the correct way:

float a = scan.nextFloat();

API guys, look here: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Scanner.html
[/quote][/quote]

plus there isn’t a check for InputMismatchException and NumberFormatExceptions
[/quote]

item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“iwasinmoparseas101class, post:19, topic:13918”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=20821.msg237407#msg237407 date=1158096620]
Once again, why do you do this:

float a = Float.parseFloat(scan.nextLine());

instead of the correct way:

float a = scan.nextFloat();

API guys, look here: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Scanner.html
[/quote][/quote]

plus there isn’t a check for InputMismatchException and NumberFormatExceptions
[/quote]
Yes, but they’re unchecked exceptions - there should still be exception handling included, but its not essential to compile at least.

item.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

import java.util.Scanner;

public class quad {

public static void main(String args[]) {
Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.print("a = ");
double a = scan.nextDouble();
System.out.print("b = ");
double b = scan.nextDouble();
System.out.print("c = ");
double c = scan.nextDouble();

double in = (b * b) - (4 * a * c);
double d = Math.sqrt(in);

double x1 = (-b + d) / (2 * a);
double x2 = (-b - d) / (2 * a);
System.out.println("X1 = " + x1);
System.out.println("X2 = " + x2);
}
}

Quadratic Equation Solver

Wrote that down during Math Class because I was really annoyed by the Formula

import java.util.Scanner; import java.io.*;

public class pythag {

public static void main(String args[]) {
Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
float a = scan.nextFloat();
float b = scan.nextFloat();
float d = a * a + b * b;
double c = Math.sqrt(d);
System.out.println("Answer is " + c);
}
}

loal, Pythagorean Solver

item.title: Number Squarer, Cuber, Square Rooter and Tangenter
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

[code] private Method updateBases(MethodGen mg, Instruction in) {
int cnt = 0;
for (int ip : mg.getInstructionList().getInstructionPositions()) {
if (mg.getInstructionList().findHandle(ip).getInstruction() instanceof InvokeInstruction) {
cnt++;
mg.getInstructionList().findHandle(ip).setInstruction(in);
if (cnt == 2)
break;
}
}
return mg.getMethod();
}

[/code]

The method name should give a clue of what it does. This and 2 other lines of code is all that is commited exclusivly to patching thier 2 methods in my updater. Of course the instruction is being pointed to the bot to handle.

Use thier external dependencies to your advantage.

WTF h0w d0 1 get th1s t0 comp1le?? plezz sh0w me h0w…

While we are posting useless code fragments…

[code]import javax.sound.midi.;
import java.io.;

public class MidiEngine{

public static void main(String args[])throws Exception {
	MidiEngine m = new MidiEngine();
	m.convieniencePlayMidi("composition.mid");
}

Sequencer sequencer;
Sequence playing;

public MidiEngine() throws Exception {
	try{
		sequencer = MidiSystem.getSequencer();
	}catch(Exception e){
		throw (e);
	}		
}

public boolean playMidi(Sequence sequence){
	try{
		playing = sequence;
		sequencer.setSequence(sequence);
		sequencer.open();
		sequencer.start();	

	}catch(Exception e){
		e.printStackTrace();
		return false;
	}		
	return true;
}

public void stopPlay(){
	sequencer.stop();
	sequencer.close();
}

public void setTempo(int tempo){
	sequencer.setTempoInBPM(tempo);
}

public void convieniencePlayMidi(String midi){
	try{
		Sequence toPlay =  MidiSystem.getSequence(new FileInputStream(new File(midi)));
		playMidi(toPlay);
	}catch(Exception e){
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

}[/code]
